Lucia, Messina, Italy Received 13 May 1994; revised 12 October 1994; accepted 17 October 1994 Abstract The reactivity of SiO> MoO JSiOe and V:Os/SiO2 in the temperature range 400-800 and at atmospheric pressure has been thoroughly investigated by temperature-programmed reaction (TPR) measurements obtaining a continuous sequence of conversion, product distribution and reaction rate data. The effect of the contact time (0.083 ~ r~ 0.332 s) on the selectivity pattern and formaldehyde productivity (STYHcuo, g kg~,,,~ h ~) has been assessed. The onset temperature of formaldehyde formation (T,,.HCHO) accounts well for the reactivity of oxide catalysts in the methane partial oxidation (MPO). For all the systems studied the same sequence of onset temperature of product formation: To.Hello < To.co < T,,.co2 < To.c, proves that formaldehyde is the primary product of MPO on silica- based oxide catalysts. A suitable procedure for the calculation of conversion-selectivity data is pointed out. Full agreement between TPR data and continuous flow (CFR) and batch reactor (BR) isothermal measurements was found. The suitability of the TPR method as a fast and reliable tool for testing oxide catalysts in MPO is assessed. Keywords." Formaldehyde: Methane; Oxide catalysts; Partial oxidation; Temperature-programmed reaction; Testing of catalysts 1. Introduction Of the different catalyst characterization methods, temperature-programmed techniques have over the last two decades received an ever increasing attention * Corresponding author. 0926-860X/95/$09.50 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSDIO926-860X( 94 )O0232-O 40 F. Arena et al. /Applied Catalysis A," General 125 (1995) 39-59 because of their powerful versatility in investigating the physico-chemical prop- erties of solid catalysts [1,2]. In this context, a method for studying catalytic reactions under temperature programming (temperature-programmed reaction, TPR) has been also proposed [2]. A number of TPR studies using supported catalysts have been mainly addressed to elucidating the reaction mechanism [2], while only few attempts have been made to use TPR as a fast method for kinetic measurements and catalyst screening [2,3]. Indeed, the transient nature of the technique could affect the reliability of catalytic results because of the occurrence of undesired diffusional and readsorption processes. In our previous paper [ 3 ] we have preliminarily outlined that the TPR method can be successfully adopted for both investigating the reactivity of oxide catalysts and accelerating the work of catalyst testing in the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde (MPO). Though a large variety of unpromoted and promoted oxide catalysts has been claimed to be effective in MPO [4-6], the unique features of the SiO2 surface in catalyzing the formation of partial oxidation products have been largely documented [7-11 ]. The roles of MOO3, V205, Nb2Os, WO3, Cr203 and other oxides on the peculiar reactivity of the S iO2 [ 4,5,12-16] and the nature of the active centres [ 4,5,15-19 ] are still topics of debate. A number of papers have addressed in particular the importance of the reaction system [4,5,9,20] and the contribution of the gas-phase and/or wall reaction [4,14,21-23] in getting valid and comparable reactivity data. Indeed, because of the constraints of the conversion-selectivity relationship, a suitable reactor device must exploit differential methane conversion per pass to ensure a high selectivity to formaldehyde, providing also finite conversion values for a reliable kinetic analysis of the data [9,16,20]. This paper is aimed to outline the high potential of the temperature-programmed reaction (TPR) technique as tool for quantitative testing of oxide catalysts in MPO. The detailed analysis of the catalytic performance of several SiO2-based oxide catalysts over a wide range of experimental conditions (temperature and contact time), obtained within the time in which a catalyst is normally tested over a narrow range of conditions by conventional methods, testifies well the great advantages of TPR for both fundamental and applied studies in catalysis. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalysts 4% MoO3/SiO2 (MPS 4) and 5% V205/SiO2 (VPS 5) catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of a 'precipitated' SiO2 (PS) support (Si 4-5P Grade, Akzo Product; BET surface area, 400 m2 g-a) with a basic solution (pH ~ 11 ) of ammonium heptamolybdate and ammonium metavanadate, respec- tively. In addition, 4.5% MoO3/SiO2 (MFS 4) and 5% V2Os/SiO2 (VFS 5) catalysts were prepared according to the above procedure by using a 'fumed' SiO2 F. Arena et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 39-59 41 (FS) support (Cab-O-Sil M5 Grade, Cabot Product; BET surface area, 200 m2 g - ~ ). After impregnation all the catalysts were dried at 90 for 24 h and then air calcined at 600 for 16 h. All the catalysts were pressed at 100 bar and subsequently crushed to obtain a particle size fraction of 16-25 mesh for use. 2.2. Temperature-programmed reaction (TPR) measurements TPR tests were performed in a conventional flow apparatus using a linear quartz reactor (I.D., 4 mm; length, 200 ram) connected on line by a heated (180) inlet capillary system (transit time<0.5 s) with a Thermolab (Fisons Instruments) quadrupole mass spectrometer for continuous analysis of the reaction mixture. TPR tests were run in the temperature range 400-800 by using 0.05 g of catalyst, a heating rate (/3) of 10 min-~ and a reaction mixture He/CH4/O2 in the molar ratio 7:2:1 flowing at a rate ranging between 25 and 100 STP ml min ~ which corresponds to a contact time, ~-, ranging between 0.083 and 0.332 s. Before the tests, catalyst samples were conditioned at 600 for 1 h under a 15% Oz/He flow. Blank tests were performed with the reactor filled with quartz wool. Mass spectra were recorded in multiple ion monitoring (MIM) mode using a SEM amplifier operating at 1500 V and a ionization potential of -70 V (total pressure, 8- 10 9 bar). TPR spectra were obtained by acquiring the signals relative to the following mass-to-charge ratios (m/z) values: 2 (H2), 4 (He), 15 (CH:~), 17 (OH), 25 (CzH), 28 (CO), 29 (CHO), 30 (HCHO), 32 (O2) and44 (CO2). Blank test In order to ascertain the contribution of the gas-phase and/or wall reaction on the activity of the investigated oxide catalysts a blank test with the reactor filled with quartz wool was performed. The related TPR spectrum, presented in Fig. 2A, displays that for T~< 600 no product is formed while at T/> 600 a very slight increase in the concentration of HCHO (m/z = 30 and m/z = 29), CO (re~z, 28) and C2 (m/z, 25) products indicates some methane conversion which rises with the reaction temperature. The conversion-selectivity trends derived from the TPR pattern are shown in Fig. 2B. It can be observed that the methane conversion values recorded in the absence of a catalyst tend to be negligible in comparison with those found in the presence of oxide catalysts (see below). In particular, methane con- version values lower than 0.1% are observed up to 700, while at higher temper- ature a sudden increase in methane conversion up to a value of 0.8% at 800 and a parallel growth in C2 selectivity (from 0 to ca. 50% at 800) occur. 46 F. TPR, CFR and BR provide essentially analogous reaction rate values over the whole investigated range of temperatures. Also the selectivity data appear to be quite similar for TPR and CFR, whilst the values of formaldehyde selectivity obtained with the BR are higher than those found with the continuous flow reactors ( TPR and CFR). TPR curves of methane conversion and product selectivity as a function of the reaction temperature (T) for PS (a), MPS 4 (b) and VPS 5 (c) samples are presented in Fig. 3. It is noteworthy to underline that a typical TPR experiment from 400 to 800, lasting 40 min, allows to acquire an enormous set of activity- selectivity-temperature points which permit to elucidate in detail the catalyst per- formance in spite of the transient regime of the TPR technique. Inspection of these data permits to gain direct insight into the main reaction pathway. It is evident that longer ~-'s cause a straight decrease in the formaldehyde selectivity and overall selectivity to partial oxidation products ( HCHO + CO) along with a concomitant increase in the carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide selectivi- ties. In fact, for zequal to 0.083 s all the systems display an almost total selectivity to formaldehyde and carbon monoxide. However, different slopes feature the trends of selectivity with ~- of the investigated samples. 4. Discussion 4.1. General The above experimental data indicate that the TPR method offers unprecedented opportunities in catalyst evaluation as well as in kinetic-mechanistic studies of MPO. In particular, the results reported in Figs. 2-5, obtained by simple calibration and data elaboration procedures, outline the powerful potentiality of the tempera- ture-programmed reactor system in achieving a quasi-continuous sequence of con- version-rate-selectivity points in a wide range of operating conditions (T and ~-) and in a time taken up by the traditional 'one point' evaluation [25]. Such an abundance of data allows a thorough evaluation of catalysts, speeding up the study of kinetics and reaction mechanism by orders of magnitude. However, in spite of the fact that the reactor is never at thermal steady-state conditions, the data reported in Table 3 document a good agreement between TPR, isothermal continuous flow (CFR) and batch (BR) reactors. The differences in the product selectivity between continuous flow reactors (TPR and CFR) and BR data are the consequence of the fact that the BR operates at quasi-zero conversion per pass over the whole inves- tigated temperature range [ 11] allowing then formaldehyde selectivity values higher than those achievable with TPR and CFR. However, the analogous values of the reaction rate obtained by such different methods undoubtedly proves the reliability of the proposed TPR method to attain accurate kinetic data in the MPO. 4.2. Onset temperature of product formation and reaction mechanism In a recent paper we have pointed out that (i) the onset temperature of formal- dehyde formation can be taken as a valid parameter for comparing the catalytic performance of silica supported oxide catalysts in the MPO at temperatures ranging 56 F. Arena et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 39 59 between 400 and 650 and (it) the sequence of onset temperature of product formation may provide valid clues about the surface reaction network [3]. According to our previous results [ 3,9,11,16,17 ], the data reported in Tables 1 and 4 indicate that MoO3 depresses the functionality of the PS support in MPO causing a marked shift of To.HCHO to a higher value (Table 1) while it exerts a promoting effect on the reactivity of the FS as documented by the lower To.HCHO value (Table 4) observed for MFS 4 sample. On the other hand, V205 addition greatly enhances the reactivity both of PS and FS surfaces [ 11,16,17,24] since we noted a considerable lowering in the To.HCHO value for both VPS 5 [ 3 ] and VFS 5 catalysts with respect to PS and FS samples, respectively. Then, it can be argued that the lower To.HCHO is, the higher is the reactivity of oxide catalysts [3]. This rule allows to trace the following reactivity scale of silica-based oxide catalysts in the MPO: FS << MFS 4 = MPS 4 < PS < VFS 5 ~ VPS 5. However, even if the addition of MoO3 and V205 promoters differently affects the original activity of the silica carriers [24], it is worthy to note that all systems studied display the same sequence of onset temperature of product formation: To.HCHO < To.co < To.co2. This sequence of the To's undoubtedly proves that formaldehyde is the primary product of the MPO reaction on SiO2-based oxide catalysts and well supports previous literature data pointing out a formaldehyde selectivity tending to unity (100%) at quasi-zero methane conversion values [12,13,18,19]. The sub- sequent formation of carbon monoxide at temperatures (To.co) slightly higher than To.HCHO indicates that such a product mainly arises from the consecutive oxidation of formaldehyde on the catalyst surface [6,13,22] according to the high tendency of such a molecule to readily undergo further oxidation to COx [ 4,13,22 ]. Whereas, the detection of carbon dioxide at even higher temperature (To.co2) than those found for either formaldehyde or carbon monoxide formation (see Tables 1 and 4) signals that such a total oxidation product likely comes from the consecutive oxidation of carbon monoxide [ 4,6,13 ] even if the contribution of a parallel reaction path at high temperatures ( > 600) leading directly to carbon dioxide cannot be completely ruled out [ 12,26]. The above hypothesis on the occurrence of a consecutive reaction path at T~< 600 is further strengthened by the straight relationship between selectivity to HCHO, CO and CO2 and ~- observed for PS, MPS 5 and VPS 5 catalysts (Fig. 6). In fact, we notice that shorter ~-'s favour a higher selectivity to formaldehyde and on the whole to partial oxidation products (HCHO + CO), while longer ~-'s cause the consecutive oxidation of formaldehyde to carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide, giving rise to a growth in the carbon dioxide selectivity. Obviously, a parallel reaction channel leading directly to carbon monoxide or carbon dioxide should imply a constant selectivity with ~-. Thus, the different trends in the product selectivity with the contact time ( Fig. 6) reflect the different ability of PS supported catalysts in promoting the oxidation of formaldehyde and carbon monoxide mole- cules. Therefore, all these findings are evidence that MPO on silica-based oxide catalysts at T.%< 600 proceeds mainly via a sequential reaction path: F. Arena et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 39-59 57 CH4 ~ HCHO ~ CO ~ CO2 in accordance to that previously proposed on the basis of steady-state [4,5,13,18] and transient [ 27] kinetic measurements. On the other hand, the concomitant formation of hydrogen and C2 products both on SiO2 (PS and FS) and MoO3/SiO2 (MPS 5 and MFS 5) catalysts at T>~ 690 (see Tables 1 and 4) indicates that coupling products form at high temperature by a different mechanism, likely involving the formation of methyl radicals (CH3) on the 'free' SiO2 surface [ 10]. The absence of such products on VPS 5 and VFS 5 catalysts can be ascribed to the high capability of V2Os-based systems in providing large amounts of activated surface oxygen species [ 16,24,27] very reactive towards CH~ radicals [ 27 ] and surface activated methane molecules [ 24]. 4.3. ActiviO,-selectivi~ pattern of MoO~ and V205 supported on different Si02 carriers According to previous literature data concerning the superior performance of 'precipitated' silica with respect to either 'fumed' or 'sol-gel' ones [9-11,17,24], our TPR data indicate that the PS sample, in the investigated temperature range (400-800), exhibits a reactivity more than one order of magnitude higher than that of the FS sample. The weak catalytic action of the FS sample implies that no carbon dioxide formation is observable up to 800 (Fig. 4a). Besides, a similar activity-selectivity pattern is found for the empty reactor (Fig. 2B) and the FS sample up to 700; at higher temperatures for the FS sample (Fig. 4a) the surface catalytic path leading to partial oxidation products (HCHO and CO) is still pre- vailing, whilst for the empty reactor (Fig. 2B ) a surface-assisted gas-phase reaction path [4-6,8,10,21,22], yielding mainly C2 products (Fig. 2B), becomes predom- inant. Furthermore, these data allow us to infer that also in the temperature range 650-800 the MPO on silica-based oxide catalysts is essentially governed by the intrinsic properties of the solids. Indeed, the regular activity-selectivity patterns of the investigated systems (Figs. 3 and 4) indicate that the reactivity fully fulfils the constraints of the conversion-selectivity relationship characteristic of a partial oxidation reaction mechanism. Besides, the activity-selectivity curves as a function of temperature are in a satisfactory agreement with the reactivity scale previously drawn on the basis of the sequence of onset temperature of product formation (Tables 1 and 4). A sudden increase in activity at T> 700 observed for both MPS 4 and MFS 4 samples (Figs. 3b and 4b) accounts for minor differences in the above reactivity scale. This pattern could be associated with a change in the reaction mechanism induced by the redox properties of the MoO3 promoter which results in higher values of the apparent activation energy for MoO3/SiO2 catalysts. 58 F. Arena et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 39 59 4.4. Influence of the contact time ('r) on the reaction rate andjbrmaldehyde productivity (STYHcHO) The negligible differences found in the reaction rate on varying the contact time (Fig. 5) lead us to rule out any diffusional control in such non-steady-state meas- urements, further confirming the validity of the aforesaid reactivity scale and reac- tion mechanism. The positive effect of shorter contact time on the STYncno'S of supported PS catalysts reflects a higher selectivity to formaldehyde, according to the aforementioned consecutive reaction pathway (Fig. 6). The temperature of the maxima in the STYncno trends can be also taken as an index of the oxidative strength of the catalysts in that a higher reactivity implies a more early occurrence of the consecutive oxidation of the primary partial oxidation product. Then, taking into account all these findings, it turns out that: (a) in the range 400-700 the following formaldehyde productivity scale results: MPS 4 < PS < VPS 5; at T>700 this order becomes: VPS 5 < PS < MPS 4; (b) very high STYncno values (500-1000 gHcno kgLtj h 1) [10] can be attained over the silica-based oxide catalysts by properly tuning of the operating conditions (T and ~-). 5. Conclusions The results reported in this work show that the temperature-programmed reaction (TPR) technique is an innovative and powerful tool which can revolutionise the field of catalyst development and the study of reaction mechanism and kinetics. Indeed, the TPR method accelerates by orders of magnitude the work of catalyst testing with the reliability of conventional steady-state methods, while also provid- ing basic insights into the surface reaction network not easily achievable from steady-state measurements. The exploitation of the proposed method has allowed to investigate the activity- selectivity patterns of several silica supported MoO3 and V205 catalysts in the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde with oxygen in the temperature range 400-800 and at various contact times. The main findings can be summarized as follows: 1. The reactivity of silica supported MoO3 and V205 catalysts depends upon the nature of the SlOE carrier. In particular, both MoO3 and V205 exert a promoting effect on the original activity of the bare 'fumed' SiO2 (FS), while the original activity of the bare 'precipitated' SiO2 (PS) is promoted by V205 and depressed by MOO3. 2. At T~< 600 the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde with oxygen on silica-based oxide catalysts proceeds mainly via a consecutive reaction path: CH4 ~ HCHO ~ CO ~ CO2 F. Arena et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 39-59 59 At T>~ 700 a parallel surface assisted gas-phase reaction pathway leads to the formation of minor amounts of C2 products on the SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 catalysts. 3. The onset temperature of product formation is a suitable parameter for obtain- ing a preliminary reactivity scale of oxide catalysts in the MPO and basic insights into the reaction mechanism. 4. V205/SIO2 catalysts allow to achieve the highest values of STYHcHO at T~< 700 because of their higher activity, whilst both SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 sys- tems ensure the highest values of STYHcHO at T> 700 owing to their high formaldehyde selectivity. The reactivity of SiO2, MoO3/SiO2 and V2O5/SiO2 in the temperature range 400–800°C and at atmospheric pressure has been thoroughly investigated by temperature-programmed reaction (TPR) measurements obtaining a continuous sequence of conversion, product distribution and reaction rate data. The effect of the contact time (0.083 ≤ ι ≤ 0.332s) on the selectivity pattern and formaldehyde productivity (STYHCHO, g kgcat −1 h−1) has been assessed. The onset temperature of formaldehyde formation (T o,HCHO) accounts well for the reactivity of oxide catalysts in the methane partial oxidation (MPO). For all the systems studied the same sequence of onset temperature of product formation: T o,HCHO < To,CO < To,CO2 < To,C2 proves that formaldehyde is the primary product of MPO on silicabased oxide catalysts. A suitable procedure for the calculation of conversion-selectivity data is pointed out. Full agreement between TPR data and continuous flow (CFR) and batch reactor (BR) isothermal measurements was found. The suitability of the TPR method as a fast and reliable tool for testing oxide catalysts in MPO is assessed.
